support.p: monument CPAT Regional Historic Environment Record: 100755 Bryn y Beddau
support.note: Described as coarse-grained, quartz-dominated sandstone, which is pale grey but has weathered to a slightly darker grey likely locally derived (Edwards 2013, 316).

layoutDesc.layout: The stone is inscribed with an Ogham inscription on the left and right edge of the Roman-letter inscribed face. The placement of the Ogham inscription, running up both to the right and left of the main face, is unusual but paralleled elsewhere in Wales such as Eglwys Gymyn 1 (CM7) and Llanwinio 1 (CM34). Both Ogham inscriptions read vertically upwards and are presumed to read in the order left then right (Edwards 2013, 316-7). The Latin inscription is in two lines, reading horizontally, approximately half-way down the stone. The combination of a horizontal Roman-letter inscription with an Ogham inscription is unusual but not unprecedented. Welsh parallels include Dolbenmaen 2 (CN18), Castell Dwyran 1(CM3) and Nevern 2 (P71) (Edwards 2013, 317).

handDesc.handNote: Both the ogham and Latin inscription are cut, not pocked. According to Macalister (1945, 376), the ogham scores are chiselled and look like knife cuts, sloped at an angle to the stem-line. The roman letters are described as small neat capitals...In line 1, S is slightly angular with triangular terminals; the lines of M are widely spaced and the diagonals meet above the line; the horizontal of L slopes downwards. In line 2, TO and CI are conjoined (Edwards 2013, 317).

history.provenance: First noted by Camden in 1594; John Lloyd recorded it and the ogham ('strokes on edges'), and sent mention to Edward Lhuyd in 1693. Published in 1848. Rhys publishes a reading in 1874.

div.p: The initial letter of the Roman-letter inscription has historically been under some debate leading to confusion surrounding its interpretation as well but the Welsh corpus asserts that SIMILINVS is secure and the inscription therefore consists of a personal name most likely followed by a title or epithet (but possibly a patronymic) meaning 'leader' (Edwards 2013, 317). About the second word in the inscription, the Welsh Corpus comments that TOVISACI/[TO]VISACI is the ancestor...of Welsh tywysog and Irish taoiseach 'leader', used here either as a title or as a second name or patronymic. It is difficult to decide which language it belongs to in the inscription - perhaps to both simulaneously (Edwards 2013, 317-9).

The Ogham inscription is generally understood to correspond to the Roman-letter inscription but a number of variations have been suggested as the vowel-notches between the consonants in the left line are either partially or fully worn (Edwards 2013, 317). The reading S[i]b[i]l[i]n[i] is based on the length of space between consonants and on the reading of the Roman-letter inscription (Edwards 2013, 317-9). On the origins of the name in the inscription, the Welsh Corpus comments that the name SIMILINI suggests a Romanized context, but that does not rule out an Irish identity for him as Latin names appear in the ogam inscriptions even in Ireland...if Similini is written with a B instead of M in the ogam version, this may be due to a very easy error in ogam (Edwards 2013, 319). It has also been argued that the change could be due to denasalization in Welsh which the Corpus notes would be early but may also indicate that the inscriber was familiar with the name Similinus in Welsh speech (Edwards 2013, 319). On the context of the stone, the Welsh Corpus comments that the monument was originally located on open moorland just above the 350m (1,150ft) contour...on the north side of the summit was a mound (one of two) [wrongfully] interpreted by John Lloyd as an artificial mound or barrow (Lhuyd 1695, 685-6)...the spot may therefore have been partly chosen for the monument and its accompanying grave in the mistaken belief that the site was an earlier place of burial...the commanding location and panoramic views indicate that the monument may have signified a claim to the surrounding land. This is also supported by the wording of the inscriptions...the massive inscribed stone might be a reused prehistoric standing stone (Edwards 2013, 317).
